answer_html: \(\displaystyle{}M(x,y)=0\) is the general solution to the ODE.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle{}M(x,y)=0$ is the general solution to the ODE.
hints_html: This equation is exact (you should verify). To solve it, “partial integration” may be useful.
hints_latex:
This equation is exact (you should verify). To solve it, ``partial
integration'' may be useful.
hints_raw: This equation is exact (you should verify). To solve it, "partial integration" may be useful.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
By differentiating \(M(x,y) = 0\) with respect to x, we arrive at \(M_x + M_y \frac{dy}{dx} = 0\) and we identify

\[\begin{aligned} M_x &= 3x^2 y + 8xy^2\\ M_y &= x^3 + 8x^2y + 12y^2.\end{aligned}\]

By computing

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}M_{xy} = M_{yx} = 3x^2 + 16xy\end{aligned}\]

we see that it is exact and hence partial integration can be used to solve it. Note that if

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}M_x = 3x^2 y + 8x y^2\end{aligned}\]

then by integrating partially with respect to \(x\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}M = x^3 y + 4x^2 y^2 + f(y)\end{aligned}\]

for some function \(f\) that does not depend on \(x\). If we differentiate

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}M = x^3 y + 4x^2 y^2 + f(y)\end{aligned}\]

with respect to \(y\) keeping \(x\) constant then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}M_y = x^3 + 8x^2 y + f'(y) = x^3 + 8x^2 y + 12y^2\end{aligned}\]

from our initial observations. We therefore find

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f'(y) = 12y^2\end{aligned}\]

so that \(f(y) = 4y^3 + C\) for an arbitrary constant C.

Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}M(x,y) = x^3 y + 4x^2 y^2 + 4y^3 + C = 0\end{aligned}\]

is the general solution to the ODE.
sols_raw:
By differentiating <math>M(x,y) = 0</math> with respect to x, we arrive at <math>M_x + M_y \frac{dy}{dx} = 0</math> and we identify

:<math>
\begin{align}
M_x &= 3x^2 y + 8xy^2\\
M_y &= x^3 + 8x^2y + 12y^2.
\end{align}
</math>

By computing

:<math>
\displaystyle{}M_{xy} = M_{yx} = 3x^2 + 16xy
</math> 

we see that it is exact and hence partial integration can be used to solve it.  Note that if

:<math>
\displaystyle{}M_x = 3x^2 y + 8x y^2
</math>

then by integrating partially with respect to <math>x</math>, we have

:<math>
\displaystyle{}M = x^3 y + 4x^2 y^2 + f(y)
</math>

for some function <math>f</math> that does not depend on <math>x</math>.  If we differentiate

:<math>
\displaystyle{}M = x^3 y + 4x^2 y^2 + f(y)
</math>

with respect to <math>y</math> keeping <math>x</math> constant then

:<math>
\displaystyle{}M_y = x^3 + 8x^2 y + f'(y) = x^3 + 8x^2 y + 12y^2
</math>

from our initial observations. We therefore find

:<math>
\displaystyle{}f'(y) = 12y^2
</math>

so that <math>f(y) = 4y^3 + C</math> for an arbitrary constant C.

Therefore,

:<math>
\displaystyle{}M(x,y) = x^3 y + 4x^2 y^2 + 4y^3 + C = 0
</math>

is the general solution to the ODE.
